Jan 26 2009 	Las Vegas amazing ... Loved New York New York.	Las Vegas has to be among the 'must go' destinations in the world and how the New York, New York lived up to expectations.My girlfriend and I stayed in a Jacuzzi room and I would recommend this upgrade for sure. The room was huge (like everything in Vegas !) and the hotel and Casino is set out in a village theme, with loads of eating / drinking opportunities for all ages/nationalities.The pool was amazing and chilled with music playing, though the drinks were slightly pricey there, they were big and worth it ! We are giving a review here about Vegas in general, a few pointers to pick the right location and things not to miss. Get on the right hand side of the plane from the UK when checking in, the window view coming through the desert into Vegas with the Canyon on you're right is amazing for those of you, like us, scared of taking a helicopter at a later stage of the holiday !The *New York New York * is opposite the MGM Grand and a perfect place to start off your journey down the famous strip !We went into every Hotel/Casino - Hooters is off the strip but close enough to walk to, it's one for the lads - say no more !A short cab ride to the Hard Rock - worth a visit.The Luxor, Excalibur and Mandalay Bay were behind us and to be honest a little too far out for our liking and not as good as the *New York New York.*Heading up the strip the Harley Davidson Cafe is a place you've gotta go to, the food is out of this world and if you like motorbikes and the rock n roll years it's the place for you.The Water Show outside Bellagio's is an experience to die for, incredible isn't the word. Caesars Palace is huge, and has a nightclub (Pure) and a fantastic bar (Pussycat Room) with world class barmen doing tricks galore. Along with the Venetian (Probably in our opinion the best hotel in the strip) and Mirage, these hotels are exceptional, bang in the the middle and in a great location to save on cab fares !We watched three shows, the Phantom of the Opera in the Venetian has to be the pick, truly sensational, get in the first ten rows for an amazing experience. Shoot "Downtown " about a 20 dollar cab ride, but catch the Stratosphere on the way, at the very end of the strip it's a great Hotel/Casino. If you are a Poker Player in Vegas for the first time, the tables are welcoming and you feel comfortable playing against the best. The Imperial Palace, centre of the strip, is also a good poker choice for the novice.The Stratosphere has a revolving restaurant (Top of the World) go there at night time the view is mind blowing - Vegas Lights from one end of the strip to the other. For the nut-jobs it has a ride that shoots you off the very top of the hotel at it's peak, 900 feet above everything in Vegas !Downtown has cheaper game play than the strip, the Golden Nugget and Four Queens are the best Casino's. The must go show to go to is "Defending the Caveman" in the Nugget. Either if you are in a relationship going nowhere, or like us one forever, you will find it funny and true to every couple's everyday life, it is also famed for sorting out sexual troubles, it will save you from those councelling sessions for sure !The light show " Downtown" was one of the highlights of our stay, Music and lights, won't spoil it for you - just go !For first time slot players, play "Wheel of Fortune" be warned you will get hooked !We saw the "O" by Cirque du Soleil in Bellagio's, not really for us, but can understand the enjoyment in some people's faces and work put into the whole show - so professional.The Cabs have a free Vegas guide, make sure you pick one up.Keep to the main streets, tip the waitresses a dollar when playing in the casino's and your drinks will be plenty and will keep on coming !As for shopping, "Las Vegas Premium Outlets" is the place to go, damn hot ( touching 100 !) but the prices are cheap for designer gear ! Bit further along from the Stratosphere - again a cab ride from the strip.As *New York New York *goes, for atmosphere, customer service, rooms, food and the Vegas experience it's a fantastic choice. A truly wonderful hotel and casino. The American breakfast bar/diner is fab."Mon Ami Gabi "close to the Paris hotel is a fantastic Parisian - style restaurant.Next time we go ( one five day trip to Vegas isn't enough !) we are looking at a more Central Location, like the Mirage or the beautiful Venetian, but in the *New York New York * we will one day return !

Jan 24 2009 	Awful experience...	the location is awesome. The room was not clean, and there was an awful smell coming out of the bathroom. We called the front desk and 2 hours later somebody showed up to clean...

Jan 24 2009 	Place to party...	For all young couples who want to get away and let it all go! My g/f and I go to Vegas once a year and stay at the NY NY every time. We love being around the younger crowd and enjoy the ROK and Coyote Ugly bars. This location is great, on the further south end, yet close to most places. The rooms were plenty big and service was outstanding. We slept later into the day and when we would leave the room I would just call and our room would be clean with in the afternoon. Go if you are young and want to kick it.

Jan 22 2009 	Nice hotel nicer slots	My GF and I decided to get married in Vegas and we decided that we would stay at New York New York. The reason for this was that we wanted to stay in one of 'Mega Resorts' and it was a hip place for two 24 year olds.The room was nice, comfy bed, nice bathroom and a safe. The only bad thing was the view, the chain lift of the roller coaster and the Project City Centre building site. The view wasn't really a problem as we would rather be on the strip than looking at it from our room.When we arrived we decided to have our bags taken by the bell hops to our room once we had checked in. This was the best thing as it took us 25 minutes to find the registration desk. Once we finally got there, the staff were friendly. Not being a huge gambler, I stuck to the penny slots (won 174 dollars) and $5 black jack. If you are a novice like me I would suggest watching a few hands and try to find a nice dealer.The hotel has lots of bars and food places all which looked nice. The only places we tried was the ESPN sports bar (get there early when NFL is on otherwise you wont get a seat) and small bar near the escalators which go down to the csino. Although a bit pricey, it was still good.All in all I would stay at NYNY agin as it has a great location in reffrence to the airport and other hotels including the monorail station at MGM.

Jan 17 2009 	New Year's Eve 	We checked into the NYNY on Dec. 28 and Checked out on Jan. 1, 2009.The purpose of our visit was to get married on the 31st and bring in the New Year at the Bridge Bash, located on the Brooklyn Bridge at the NYNY.We booked two rooms Park Ave. with strip view, and many of our guests stayed at the NYNY. Check in was fast, we requested our bags to be brought up to our room; it took about an hour for the bags to arrive, which I thought was quite reasonable for the amount of people checking in. The Hotel left us a message to apologize for the delay and reduced our first night rate by 25.00 for the inconvenience. Both rooms were clean and seemed to have been recently updated. All the staff was polite and helpful. Overall our expectations were exceeded at the NYNY. Would highly recommend this hotel anyone.

Jan 17 2009 	NYNY Is Great!	I booked on the hotel website 8 months in advance, and checked again 10 days before leaving the UK and noticed there was a much better offer available. I cancelled the original booking for no charge, and re-booked for the better offer which saved us $250 over 5 nights.We arrived at about 4pm on New Years Eve, and check in took less than 10 minutes. We stayed in the New Yorker tower, in a Park Avenue room overlooking the roller coaster and facing the strip. I was concerned about noise from the roller coaster, but apart from the occasional scream, I didnt really hear it. It stops at 11pm, except at the weekend when it stays open until midnight. I was very surprised that hotel guests still have to pay $14 for 1 ride  at that price I didnt think it was worth it.We were disappointed that the room did not have any tea or coffee making facilities  we really thought a 4 star hotel should offer this, but we were told to call room service instead (obviously for a charge)!The room was a good size, although starting to show its age. The carpet had some stains by the window, and if you pulled the curtains back you could see the wallpaper was peeling away and the plaster was crumbling. The safe is built into the wall, and is very small. You could not put a laptop or SLR camera inside. We had just enough space for our passports, wallets and mobile phones. The room had a large CRT telly with about 30 channels. The beds were very comfortable.There was a good all-you-can-eat breakfast buffet at one of the casino restaurants, and the America restaurant had an all-day breakfast menu with most items $8 to $12. There is no buffet for an evening meal, but you can easily walk to the MGM Grand or Luxor, which both have an evening buffet.This was my first trip to Vegas and overall I was very impressed. Although the NY NY is at the bottom end of the strip, there is a bus that stops outside the MGM Grand, and goes all the way to the other end. It is only $5 for a 24 hour pass. My only other disappointment was that the pool was closed for the winter period, and there was no inside pool, but apparently no Vegas hotel does.

Jan 13 2009	Don't let the bad reviews keep you from staying here!	Went to Vegas for the NFR and cowgirl daughter's 21rst birthday. Was skeptical after reading negative reviews, but got a decent rate and decided to go for it. We haven't anything bad to say about our hotel experience. The staff were super friendly, actually exceptional considering the amount of people they deal with and check-in was a breeze. We asked for adjoining rooms or as close as possible and staff worked with us, we were one room away from each other! I couldn't believe it! Hotel elevators and casino were easy to navigate. We stayed three days in Park Ave view rooms (view is really the roof of casino and roller coaster which wasn't operating) Room was tastefully decorated, clean and roomy especially the incredible bathroom. As far as the casino, I had not been to Vegas for years and was shocked at the prices of everything from a beer to a Nathan's dog. Cocktail service was sketchy at best at the slots. Slots were not loose and tables are $$$. We watched the Steelers win at the ESPN zone which was fun but again overly expensive. Had it not been raining/snowing I think we would have went elsewhere for our gambling and dining, especially since NYNY is centrally located. We were also disppointed with the removal of the "Central Park" trees and the bizarre construction of the middle of the casino floor, very very tacky looking.
Jan 12 2009 	Good for families	This was a good hotel for families, room were adequate, not huge, food choice great and plenty for the kids to do. Its huge bur good value for LV.

Jan 10 2009 	Awesome Hotel!	We stayed at this hotel for 5 nights and it was fantastic!The rooms are very clean, the service was amazing and the location is perfect.The casino area is smaller then the MGM but still enough casino to have loads of fun.We loved the NY-NY!

Jan 9 2009 	Great casino nice rooms	Stayed 4 nights (arrived Saturday) at New York-New York, Las Vegas, with my husband, also had 2 friends staying at same hotel (all under 30). Good sized rooms, nice bathrooms, comfortable bed but noisy air-conditioner. The casino was really cool, lots of places to eat & drink. Nothing fabulous about view from our room on the 32nd floor. Will stay at Treasure Island next time if the price is similar, looked really fun & centrally located. However, will stay at New York's again if cheaper than TI. Don't waste your money on the train to get around the strip, the buses are much quicker, cheaper & you won't be walking as much. Suggest you plan your trip to be here on the weekend no matter what the cost, this town can get pretty quiet on weekdays out of peak season.

Jan 6 2009 	Dream (Match) Come to Life	I love Manny Pacquiao and saw him fight live two times in '08. Here was my opportunity to see him for a third time since he was showing up in Vegas again to fight Oscar De La Hoya. Although tickets were sold out the day they were released, I was fortunate enough to get them less than a week before the actual fight. Prior to deciding to get the tickets I had to find a place to stay for my girl and myself. After weeks and weeks of research, I decided NY NY was the best deal in town. Since the fight was at the MGM Grand, the location was close enough to walk (a bridge length) and at the same time save some money compared to the surrounding hotels on the strip and the MGM itself. My girl and I stayed for 2 days in the Skyline room accommodation and were very pleased to say the least. Our room had nice views including the roller coaster facing MGM. The bed, pillows and sheets were pretty comfortable. Good size room with ample space in the bathroom is all we could ask for. However, the casino itself in my opinion is not my favorite. I'm not a big gambler so I don't really care, but what stood out in my mind was the relatively small size of the layout of the casino and especially all the smoking going on which irritated me greatly. I'm fortunate and grateful that NY NY had affordable rooms available during this exciting weekend event. Had they not, I probably would not have been motivated to locate fight tickets and been able to attend and witness the beat down of De La Hoya by my main man and idol, Manny "Pac-Man" Pacquiao! Yee!

Jan 3 2009 	A disappointing stay at NYNY Hotel	My husband and I decided to take advantage of Travelocity's Vegas packages and spend 2 nights at New York - New York. We've stayed in Vegas before, at Excalibur. In the past, we walked through NYNY's casino and were impressed with the air filtration, but not this time. We booked a Park Avenue room, and upon check in, we easily upgraded a non-smoking Spa Suite room. The upgrade cost was $55 for the weeknight (Thurs, 1/1) and $90 for the weekend night (Fri, 1/2). Our room was in the New Yorker tower. We were surprised there was not a staff member asking to see your room key like Excalibur has before accessing the elevators. Our room was tastefully decorated with a clean spa tub. However, a significant amount of the grout in the shower was black with mildew and in a few spots appeared to be damaged due improper repair or so badly damaged from mildew and mold it appeared to be rotten. It made me wish I brought flip flops to wear in the shower. There were knobs missing from the chest of drawers and the picture quality from the satellite TV was poor. What is the point of a large flat screen TV if the picture quality or reception is bad. The casino's air quality was poor. We ended up gambling in Excalibur, Luxor, and Mandalay Bay instead. Our dinner at Nine Fine Irishmen was great. We've never been disappointed with Nine Fine Irishmen's food or service. On both mornings around 8:00 am, we were awakened by groups on people shouting in the hallways. Upon checking out, we reported the mildew and received a $20 dollar credit for each night. In the future, we'll stay at Mandalay and only visit NYNY for dinner at Nine Fine Irishmen.

Jan 2 2009 	Once again we love NYNY	This was our 6th trip to Las Vegas and our 4th stay at NYNY. As a point of reference we have also stayed at the Mirage and the Aladdin (now Planet Holleywood). New York New York still remains our favorite. As a sidenote, we had a free hotel room offered to us at Hooters Casino. Two days prior to the trip we decided not to chance a new hotel that was not directly on the strip and paid to stay at NYNY. What a great choice! We checked out the room we would have had at Hooters (ok but not what we would want on a trip to Vegas).Check in was easy. We had an offer through the Players Club which gave us great rates and a Park Avenue Deluxe room. I asked for a room with a good strip view and we got it. We were at the corner of the hotel with a view of the strip, the airport, and the mountains in the distance. Loved it. Our room was just as I remembered, comfortable, fairly contemporary, and clean. That's all we need in Vegas.We played mostly at NYNY because we really like the vibe there. Everything seems to be laid back. Our drinks were comped everytime we sat down at a table or machine. And service was fast. (We are tippers-so this might account for the fast and attentive service-we usually tip a dollar a drink) I mention this because we had a bad experience at the Mirage-we found the Mirage to be impressive but not our style. I can't describe it other than we sit at 10 dollar tables and play 25 cent machines. We are not high rollers and were treated as such. On the other hand we always feel comfortable and taken care of at NYNY.We ate at both ESPN Zone, Americana, and Gonzales y Gonzales. All of our meals were good. My husband is a big sports bettor so ESPN Zone works out GREAT for watching the games. The food is good, not great, but its a sports bar what can you expect. Americana is a great choice for breakfast. Once again food was good and service was excellent. Gonzales y Gonzales was really good and the margaritas were GREAT. Our favorite new touch to the hotel is the circular bar in the middle of the casino. The bartenders were great and there was always a seat available for video poker.I think this casino/hotel is great if you want a laid back, fun, young environment. If you want the wow factor, this is not the casino for you. My parent are travelling to Vegas this month, we booked them at the Wynn (thats more there style). As for us, NYNY is perfect for a relaxing fun trip.

Jan 2 2009 	A really nice hotel. I would definitely stay here again.	We stayed in an upgraded room which was quite large. My only complaint was that the bed was covered with an old fashioned bedspread that had probably been used again and again. Other than that, the room was very clean, the mattress, very comfortable. The bathroom was modern and large. The problem for some guests might be that the room overlooked the rollercoaster. The noise of the rollercoaster was not the problem but the screams of the riders could be heard. The rollercoaster did not stop running until 12:00 p.m. so if you are a light sleeper, it might be a problem. It was not for us.

Dec 30 2008 	Okay	First stay at this hotel (usually room at MGM, Mirage or the Venetian), but received a 3-night stay at NYNY just before the Christmas holidays. The room was a Park Avenue Deluxe on a corner of the hotel with wrap around windows. A nice touch, but the room was small compared to other hotels on the Strip, and felt crowded even with a couple of bags. Linens fading with wear, the room is getting old and is in need of a reno.Hotel staff was friendly, but the restaurant food was below what you would expect (unenjoyable really) and over-priced. Nightlife is always fun in NYNY, but on this trip a couple of the bars/pubs were closed until 2009. Definitely a good enough hotel to get some sleep since it is in a good location and easy to catch a taxi, but would not recommend if you are looking for a hotel to call home on your trip. You wouldn't stay here for the gaming, eating or entertainment.Also - the pool looked incredibly small. Would not want to stay here when the pools are open in Vegas. You'd be very disappointed. If you enjoy wasting a better part of your afternoon by the pool, stay at MGM, Venetian, Casears, etc.

Dec 28 2008 	Decent but much better options. Very rude staff uncomfortable astmosphere.	We stayed a couple nights at the New York, New York after I recieved a promotion from being a member of the playersclub. We usually stay at other MGM properties, but figured we would give the New York, New York a shot as the casino and hotel do have a funky young feel to it. However, there are very clear warnings that go along with this hotel that did sour the experience;First; Check-in/out. The front desk in this hotel is woefully under-staffed and very inefficient. There were long lines when we checked in and out. The hotel check-in is also visible from the casino and it did not seem that our experience was any different than most peoples (even at odd times of the day!). The most glaring example was a very large line at 7am one morning. Staff: I was quite shocked by the rudeness of the staff in the hotel and the casino. Maybe they take the New York theme a bit too far? there is no reason to be overtly rude to people. Some examples were being completely ignored for drink service (one time we actually asked for drinks and were dismissed by the waitress with I'll get around to you' - she never did come back after several hours.. Other examples were people getting chewed out at the front desk and playersclub for legit errors (from what I observed waiting in the obscenely long lines). Food: There are several food options in the Hotel, All of them incredibly over-priced (even with the 20% off coupons that they dish out!). None of them very appetizing. Avoid the ESPN Zone, completely smoke and mirrors place - it was one of the worst restaurants I have ever had the displeasure of eating in. Frozen burgers, really? Thats just lazy, cheap and stupid (esp for $15!).Rooms: Decent and well decorated rooms, but not terribly clean.. mold rampant in the bathroom. Looked as if it was a very cheap build, grout falling out, mouldy silicon interface of the tub. Sink counter-tops not installed properly. We had to request a new room after the first night as they put us directly beside the elevator shaft - don't bother accepting this room if you can help it, you won't sleep. They didn't really question us too hard when we asked for a new room, a few others in line were asking for the same reason. I guess the desk staff is used to it.Value: Well, unless they give you the room extremely cheap or for free I would suggest staying elsewhere. We don't vacation to feel uncomfortable. The Monte Carlo is a much better option and usually a comparable price.. although an older and more subdued crowd there.

Dec 27 2008	Loved the New York New York	Daughter wanted to see Las Vegas for her 21st birthday, so I did alot of research before choosing the New York, New York. I was glad I made the right decision. Getting to the hotel from the airport was easy - a five minute taxi ride. We arrived at 10:30 AM Pacific Time so I was a little concerned about not being able to check in for a few hours, but no sooner did we get out of the cab that a bellman came over, tagged our luggage, and held it for us until our room was ready and we could call to bring it up. Checking in at that hour, there wasn't anyone at the registration desk so we checked in right away. I asked for a roll a way bed as we had three people in the room and the queen size beds weren't going to big enough for three people. Since we booked our plane and hotel reservations through US Airways, there was no charge for the rollaway and the registration clerk ordered it for us. We did not have to wait for our room to be ready and after we grabbed a quick bite to eat at the American Restaurant, we checked out our room and by then the rollaway had already arrived. After placing the call for our luggage it took no more than 5 minutes for it to arrive at our room. The staff was very friendly and accommodating. The ambience of the hotel was overwhelming. The American Restaurant wasn't so great so we ate there just once. We at twice at the Chin, Chin Cafe, like their chinese food and their prices were reasonable. We also ate there for breakfast. The night of my daughter's birthday we splurged at Gallagher's. Although the food was excellent, it was very pricey. The village eateries, which had an array of eaterys (Starbucks, Ben & Jerry's, fish place, dessert eatery, Nathan's hotdogs) was picturesque with tables set up all throughout which made it appear that you were eating at outdoor cafes. You couldn't hear the noise from the casino, so it was a good place to escape the noise, smoke and music if you wanted to. The roller coaster was OK, not the best ride I ever had, very bumpy. The shoulder harness should be replaced with over the head/chest harness like other roller coasters and the headrest was not cushioned. My shoulder's and neck hurt for three days after I rode the ride. I wouldn't ride it again. Alot of archade games for the kids on the second for those kids who under 21 - something to keep them busy. Hotel is across the street from the MGM Grand where you can catch the monorail. This hotel is conveniently located.

Dec 24 2008 	Incredible Views Excellent Service	Check in was a breeze. We got there about 7 at night, and we waited like 3 minutes in line. Even though the rate I booked was under the "Room Upgrades through 2009 Free" program, I tried the $20 trick to make sure we got a better room. The person checking us in declined the tip, and gave us the upgrade. And boy what an upgrade! Yeah, it was just to the next room size, 400 sq feet total, but the view was incredible - we had a corner room, 20th floor, with a view of the strip and the airport - and the sunrise, when we cared to get up that early (or stayed up that late!). The bed was as comfortable as the Temperpedic we have at home.Yeah, we had to tip multiple times for baggage service - once to the person taking bags from the car, and once to the person bringing them up to the room. But hey, that's Vegas. Just about everyone we talked to there was knowledgeable. When we accidentally kept the "Do Not Disturb" sign on the room one night, there was a message on our phone when we got back late offering to get us fresh towels, which was also excellent. While the Casino is as big as most of the others in Vegas hotels, it was easy to navigate. Never got lost, and it was easy to find the restaurants within.And the rate was less than the Motel 6 down the road. An excellent deal in our book!

Dec 23 2008 	Loved it...would recommend to anyone under 40....	Great stay. NY NY has something for everyone. Good food, great bars and helpful staff...I would definately recommend the Bar at Times Square - drinks are expensive but worth every penny for the atmosphere...

Dec 23 2008 	Still like it but loved the old design	The construction is finally done at this hotel. And my first impression---big disappointment. I loved the old hotel because it reminded me of parts of NYC when I was in the lobby. Now its all neon and weird spacing. Its like they forgot their theme was New York City. Im also not impressed with the new Central bar. It looks like something new and modern and stark. That is so not New York City. Basically the hotel lost its personality in trying to match newer Vegas hotels. On the plus side, the 24 bar next to Coyote Ugly rocks with super friendly bartenders and Gallaghers still cooks a mean steak. I also suggest going to Il Fornaio in the lobby for a quick casual bitesandwiches, salads, pastaI dont think Ive ever had anything bad there. Simply fantastic food and you wouldnt know by passing it. Club---The nightclub ROK is also finally open. We, as women will lol, got in free and they had free champagne all night. But let me help you---buy a drink. Cheap champagne = nasty! The club itself, while on the small side, was fun and service was fast. The bathrooms are unisex so be ready when you walk in. The crowd leans toward fun, drunk and ready to party vs. posers ala Pure nightclub so we liked it. Hotel roomIve stayed here enough to know to stay in the Broadway rooms. They are older but much bigger than the new rooms. And theyre still clean and very decent so the age isnt showing badly at all. I hate paying for internet but whatever. Would I stay here again? Sure, because the fun 30-ish people stay here, lol. But it's going to take me a second to forgive them for going neon tacky.

Dec 17 2008 	NYNY left something to be desired	Before we arrived at the hotel, the players club informed us as long as we played, they would comp our food and drink. My husband and I brought what we could afford budget wise due to the economy and played blackjack the entire time. The last day, my husband went to the players club and was informed we would not be comped anything. As it turns out, they do not start to comp you until you have spent $1000 gambling. Not only had we spent most of our time in the hotels when the card was applicable, but we made sure to eat there as well - for no reason! So the deal is that if you have money and don't need the comps, that is when you get reimbursed. It is very disappointing to see a business run like that. Most of the dealers that we had in the hotel were rude and rarely smiled despite us trying to get them to joke with us. One actually made me feel downright uncomfortable so we left the table. The gaming area was incredibly small compared to all the other hotels. The good things I can say the room we had was nice, though our friends' was run down. Gallegher's is a very good restuarant and the bartenders at The Bar at Times Square were excellent. That being said, we will not be going back to that hotel again.

Dec 14 2008 	great stay	We got a great deal when we booked it through the hotel's website. We were upgraded to a Park Ave Deluxe room with 2 free drink vouchers, 2-for-1 rollercoaster ride and other offers. The room had two queen beds that were very comfortable. The bathroom had a small fridge with ice maker hidden under the sink. The shower's water pressure was the best! Both the room and bathroom were very clean. The service was magnificent. The pool area wasn't big enough. We weren't able to use our drink vouchers at the poolside bar, even though we were told that we were able to. We went on the rollercoaster late at night. It was a great experience. The food/restaurants there are great. Overall, I had a great stay.

Dec 13 2008 	Cool hotel	There was a good buzz about the hotel, loved the walkways connecting it to the MGM and the Excalibur, made exploring easier! Stayed in one of the players suites, huge room, only had a view of the carpark, but we didnt spend much time looking out the window! The hotel is slightly old, but it wouldn't put me off this place. The food court was great, the pizza slices are to die for! The best thing about the hotel however was the dueling pianos at the bar at time square. this was one of the highlights of our stay, i cant express just how much fun it was! Those guys are so talented and great entertainers! just be prepared to bring some cash if you want to get your song played!! And dont let the $15 charge to sit down put u off - stand for free, makes dancing easier!!

Dec 12 2008 	Had a great time!	Stayed here Nov 30 to Dec 3rd and loved every minute of it. We arrived quite early in the morning, around 10am, and a room was ready and prepared for us. The room was clean, quiet and had a nice view of the Rollercoaster, which was kind of fun. The bathroom was pretty big and the shower was great and the bed was super comfortable.We got a good deal on the room and loved the location, and could catch a bus on the other side of the pedestrian bridge by the MGM. The casino/gambling isn't top notch but there are so many casinos to gamble at, that it more than sufficed. I was looking to play some poker, and just walked across the street to the MGM and played in their poker room, as it's nice to switch it up from Casino to Casino anyway.Check out was easy, the "food court" area downstairs had plenty to offer at all hours of the day and overall the experience was great. I would definitely recommend it if you're looking for good place to stay in Vegas that is close to everything you need.

Dec 11 2008	Will try another hotel next time	Location: Excellent. On the south end of the strip which was close to most of the casinos/activities we wanted to see/do. The main shopping area is mid-strip though, so would not stay here if your intention is only to shop (only a 30-40 minute walk to the shopping area though). Or you can take a tram.Room: We stayed in the Park Avenue Deluxe. Nicely decorated, quite clean. We requested a non-smoking room with a king bed and we received a non-smoking room with two queen beds which was fine. My main complaint was the noise. I booked this hotel fearing I would get a room close to the coaster. It was not as bad as some others have described it, but it depends where your room is and how high up it is. I could not hear the coaster with the TV on, and it stops running before midnight, so not a huge deal, but just something to be aware of because the constant rumbling is there. The walls are paper thin and I could hear every conversation going on next door even if they were talking normally. Drove me crazy since they were up until the wee hours of the morning talking. I also found the mattresses and pillows to be extremely uncomfortable.Overall: Because of the noise from the coaster/hotel neighbors, and the extremely uncomfortable beds, I would not stay here again. I only paid about $100 US a night though so I had a pretty good experience based on what I paid. If I had paid more though I would not have thought it was worth it. What I did like was the location (and the elevators up to the room were very fast) but will try the MGM Grand next time.

Dec 9 2008	Okay I guess	Stayed at the hotel from Dec 4 - 7 2008. When we got in, right away we smelled the smokiness inside..blah. Check in wasn't a problem. Our room was okay but our bathroom was small. Our 1st I checked out our hotel....that was it as I mainly went out on the Las Vegas Strip. It was a busy since there was the Rodeo event plus the De la Hoya - Pacquiao fight at MGM Grand (next door to NY NY Hotel). The walls were "paper thin" as we can hear our neighbors. Plus also some people was so loud out on the hallway waking us up at 3am in the morning, but hey it's Vegas! Overall we may go back to NY NY for the price...but prefer to find a better hotel.

Dec 8 2008 	NY NY - Take It Or Leave It	My husband and I stayed at NY NY from November 26th thru Novemebr 29th. Check-In was a breeze....our plane landed us a bit before 11:00am and we were at the hotel by 12:00. They did have a room ready for us...standard/king. I asked for a strip view and they wanted to charge me $15 per day. I told the clerk that the mountains are just fine for me to look at...who goes to LV for a view, anyways. The room was nice...nothing too special. The bed was comfortable and the room was clean. The only problem, there was no happy medium to the temperature...it was either cold or hot. One morning, we could hear our neighbors very clearly, I thought they were in our room, but we were leaving to go onto the strip, so it was not too bothersome...but be advised, walls are thin. I was a bit disappointed with the casino itself. The table games were great...friendly dealers, good minimums, etc. However, I enjoy playing the slots as well and their slots were not special. No fun games...I like Elvis, Wheel of Fortune, Top Dollar, etc. It all seemed the same and nothing to WOW me. Other casinos, however, had the same table games and better slots, so I went elsewhere the majority of the time...Monte Carlo had $5 table limits and better slots.As for the little restaurants in NY NY, nothing to write home about. The pizza shop was disgusting...the bottom of my supreme slice was so greasy that my pizza was actually soggy. Left a bad taste in my mouth to say the least. Nathans was much better for that quick bite to eat. DO NOT eat at the pretzel shop upstairs for a snack unless you have a taste for cardboard. We were disappointed on Thanksgiving...no buffet or good specials at NY NY. We walked over to MC and ate at CAFE for a great turkey dinner. I cashed in some points for a free dinner. The food there was yummy!!!! When are stay was over, check-out was simple. I requested a later check-out and they granted me a noon check-out instead of 11:00am. All in all, NY NY was okay...I have stayed better, I have stayed worse. I think that NY NY is losing their pizazz from the very beginning of their opening...they are going downhill. I hope they can pick it back up because I used to enjoy it!

Dec 3 2008 	New York New York 1st anniversary in Vegas	I was very skeptical about staying at this hotel because the reviews were so random. I must say that it was a nice experience. There was nothing extra special or extra horrible. The room that we had was the Park Ave Deluxe room and they said they upgraded us to a better view. I must say that the room was a lot smaller then I was use to but we made due. We had a really nice view of the MGM and the roller coaster. The staff was rather pleasant and I loved the pizza shop in the hotel. The roller coaster ride was AWESOME! As a native New Yorker I thought it was a cute rendition of the city. Vegas was wonderful and the hotel was just cool nothing to write home about. The room was clean the bed was not hard and room service was rather quick.

Dec 2 2008	Sept trip to Las Vegas	Stayed the middle of Sept for two nights at New York New York. Unfortunately the lobby construction did create a high noise factor which detracted from the gambling experience. The staff was polite when there was a misunderstanding about our on-line booking and we were granted our Strip View Room. The roller coaster did not disturb our sleep. Also spent one night on Treasure Island. The beds were wonderful. Great View. Ana from New York checked us in. I had read a bad review about her attitude but she was very courteous to us. Great experience at Treasure Island. We enjoyed their casino the most. TI breakfast buffet was delicious.

Dec 2 2008	Decent at best.	I stayed at NYNY Nov 24-26. I booked my flght and hotel with NWA.com, and paid $305 for flight and hotel, so I got a great deal. On my previous trips I always liked going to NYNY and wanted to stay there. Unfortunately they have changed the coolest part of the place. The casino used to be themed after Central Park, with trees and green park-like structures over the playing tables. The trees are gone and the structures have been replaced and are now topped with weird neon lights. Upon check in I asked for a room away from the roller coaster, the front desk person said no problem. I was put in room 2101, a Park Avenue room. Getting up the to 21st floor the room just happened to be on the far end of the hallway, so there was a long walk from the elevators. The room itself was nothing special, a little on the small side. It appeared the decor had recently been redone, but TV was still the old tube style. The bathroom was tiny. The last time I went to Vegas I stayed at Planet Hollywood and their bathrooms were almost 3 times the size of NYNY's. Not only that but the towels seemed to be quite old, as they had lost the softness to them. They seemed like towels you would get at a Holiday Inn Express. The shower was also a combo with the tub, I prefer them seperate but thats not a big deal, it had good water pressure. The bed was decently comfortable, a little firm for me, but I guess that is personal preference. Of course I looked out of my window, which was overlooking the pool, and there is the "drop" in the roller coaster. The noise wasn't too bad from it but you could hear it, especially if people were on it and screaming.Getting out of the room, went down to the casino. Being that Vegas's tourism is way down, the limits were the lowest I have seen them at NYNY, at almost anytime you could get a $5 blackjack table. Granted most of the them were usually with the auto-shufflers. The sports/racebook sucks. It is small with some individual monitors for race bettors. With ESPNZone next to it, it seems that this is their way around giving drinks out to bettors, since ESPN's dinning room, looks like most other sportbooks. I went down to Bellagio to watch the Saints-Packers MNF game and put down $50 on the Saints. I was given free drinks (Jameson/Cokes, and Vodka/Redbulls.) then entire length of the game, without the server even caring if I put down a bet or not.I only ate two places at NYNY, one was great the other was not. One of the best reasons to visit NYNY is the pizza place. Great pizza and not too expensive. I was able to get a regular slice of peppironi and a beer for $8. The other place I ate was ESPNZone. This was not that good and was quite expensive. I had asked for a cheeseburger and got some sort of mayo on it. Most places I usually go do not have mayo on it, that aside the burger just wasn't very good. Which is sad since the night before I was able to get a great burger at Kahunaville, at NYNY's sister hotel Treasure Island. I went out to the hot tub on tuesday morning, mostly to soak the feet after a day and night of walking around, and was planning on going back later, but it was closing at 4pm. I found this odd, I would have figured pools in Vegas would be open almost 24 hours, well at least the hot tubs, but whatever, maybe this is their way of getting you to upgrade to a suite.Overall I was not impressed with NYNY. I think the only way I would stay there again is if I was going to a fight at MGM, as it is right across the street. Other than that I would stay farther north on the strip.

Dec 1 2008 	Lower end hotel	This is hotel 3 of 4 for the week. We stayed at 3 others just so we could see the whole strip and experience different things through the week.We arrived early here, and after the long walk to the hotel from the parkade we were able to check in earlier. Upon check in the desk staff pushed to spend the extra 20 a night for the bigger room, it was definitely not worth it. The room was almost too big, and not worth the money. The whole floor smelled bad, and just didn't appear to be even dusted. The beds were good enough to sleep on, and the shower was quite tiny, just don't look at the vent in the shower, as ours was really disgusting as it was packed and I mean literally packed with dust. The shower didn't drain all that well, neither did the sink. The food was horribly over priced here, and wasn't all that good. We ended up walking to the Luxor and the Excalibur, and for all being owned by the same company. The other 2 hotels were amazing, the Excalibur had a great food court, so did the Luxor. The shopping was better in the other 2 hotels, and for some reason as pushy as the time share people are down there, they seemed to be even worse at the new york new york. It's a good location but I would never stay there again, I would stay at the Excalibur as it's not that much more. The location was ok, we walked across to the MGM grand to catch the monorail, which is a great value by the way. And we did the strip that way it's much easier and felt safer too. We got off and walked to the Bellagio and watched the fountains, and began the half an hour walk back to the new york new york, it really didn't look that far!Gambling there was a waste of time, 3 of us lost over 60 bucks in 15 minutes, ON PENNY MACHINES. We had much more fun at the Luxor, or even Caesars palace. All in all, this hotel was not worth the money. It was old, It was dirty, and just plain boring. There was not a lot to do at this hotel, there wasn't as much shopping as there was in the Excalibur or the Luxor. The only thing I can recommend is if you stay here, walk across to the MGM and look at the lions, they are amazing.

Nov 30 2008 	New York New York - Nice But No "Vibe"	My wife and I recently returned from a four-night stay at New York New York Hotel to celebrate my birthday. We stayed from November 17th to November 21st and although this was our tenth trip to Vegas, this was our first stay at NYNY. From worst to best, the other hotels we've stayed at have been - Circus Circus, Bally's, Planet Hollywood, Treasure Island, Mirage, and Venetian. Among those hotels, I would have to place NYNY between Bally's and Planet Hollywood. The look of NYNY was quite impressive, but I found the over-all vibe somewhat lacking. More on that later. The hotel is designed with a mixture of 1920's art deco and modern New York style, but the combination works. The valet area where the taxi dropped us off looked like the grand entrance to a 1920's hotel. The front desk is located only a short walk from the valet entrance and the front desk personnel, as well as the valet, were very friendly. We booked the 5th Avenue Deluxe package that gave us a free upgrade from a standard Skyline room to a Park Avenue Deluxe room and believe me, the room looked just as nice as it did on the website. The hotel rooms are divided among four towers - the Century tower, the Empire tower, the Chrysler tower, and the New Yorker tower which is where we stayed. Each tower has it's own bank of elevators with about ten elevators in each bank serving certain floors. The result is a very short wait for elevators going up, or coming down. The halls to the rooms look as if you are in an apartment building. The smaller the last two digits of your room number are, the further you are from the elevator. We were in room 1408 so we were pretty far. The room itself, although kind of small, was very nice and cozy. It felt more like an apartment than a hotel room. The room had a king-size bed, two cushioned chairs, an ottoman, a marble table, two bedside tables with lamps, an iHome radio with iPod dock (The radio won't work with the iPhone), a writing desk and chair with a large mirror and lamp, an additional lamp in the corner, and a large armoire with closet space on each side which holds the iron and ironing board and three large drawers. The armoire also holds a 32" T.V., but it's not a flat screen like many other hotels are upgrading to. The bathroom is all marble with a shower/tub combo with sliding glass frosted doors. The bathroom wasn't that big, and the water pressure left something to be desired, but it was nice all the same. Some rooms have foyers like ours did and some don't. We had a free safe on the wall in our foyer. You punch in a four-digit code and you can use it as much as you want. The safe won't fit anything big, but it works for small valuables. The room we were in had a wall of windows on the south side facing Flamingo Ave, and on the east side facing Las Vegas Blvd. The armoire was in front of the east windows though, but that was okay we still had nice views and lots of sunlight in the morning and lots of neon light at night. We also had a direct view of the roller coaster a couple hundred yards away, but the noise level was barely a whisper. As nice as the room was, we did encounter a few problems. The comforter on our bed had some questionable stains and hair on the underside. We called housekeeping and not only did they change the comforter, but they changed all the sheets as well. The housekeeper told us that they change the sheets after each guest, but not the comforter, but they will if the new guest requests it. We also had a burned-out light in our armoire, and our iron didn't work. Both problems, along with the comforter situation, were handled quickly and very professionally. The comfort of the bed was okay, not bad - not great. It felt like a regular bed, nothing like the bed at TI which is the best bed I ever slept in. Our package, along with the free upgrade, also included two free drinks redeemable at Nine Fine Irishmen pub, or Pour 24, the 24-hour bar on the mezzanine level, a 2 for 1 ticket for the roller coaster, discounted spa treatment, and a 2 for 1 breakfast on the patio of the Italian restaurant Il Fornaio. The coupon is for your entree only. Not for sides or beverages. We ordered French toast and it was delicious. They do great coffee, eggs, and bacon as well. They are definitely worth a try. Although we didn't swim, we visited the pool which is open until early December. The pool is very small and under the shadow and noise of the roller coaster. Not relaxing at all without much sun. When I said earlier that NYNY lacks a "vibe", I meant that there's not much to keep you there. It's nice walking through the recreation of the neighborhoods, but they've taken out most of Central Park to replace it with a casino bar which, as of this writing, is still under construction. Their shopping is virtually non-existent consisting of a few souvenir shops, a watch shop and one "upscale" clothing store that looks just like another souvenir shop, and you can find equal or better food choices at other hotels. There is no buffet although the Asian themed Chin Chin has a daily breakfast buffet. The bars like Nine Fine Irishmen and the dueling piano bar have live music, but you have to buy two drinks in the afternoon, and at night they become just another pretentious spot with doormen and a cover. The Coney Island arcade is cool, but if you're not a kid or if video games and cheap prizes for tickets aren't your thing then you won't care. The casino is not well organized, and the sports book is tiny. They also have time-share and rental property sellers at practically each entrance - inside the hotel. We've all seen them by other hotels, but to have them inside the hotel jumping you coming and going is very annoying. One thing I can say though, is that during the time we were there the weather was amazing (sunny and warm every day - cooler at night) and the crowds were incredibly thin with hardly any kids around. The lines for the clubs were so short that your chances of getting in were very good. In fact, they were practically begging for people to come in. Check-out was very quick, in fact, you can check out through your t.v. and drop your key off at the key deposit by the elevators, but only if you haven't incurred any in room charges. Check-out is normally 11:00 a.m., but if you need an extra hour you can call the front desk and request a 12 noon check-out for no extra charge. Like I said earlier, NYNY is a very nice hotel and you should try it, for the right price, but aside from the fact that my wife and I don't like to visit the same hotel too many times anyway, I can't really see returning to NYNY when there are other more exciting hotel choices. By the way, if you are looking for some entertainment and food choices, you can't go wrong with these - For burgers In N Out Burger is the only way to go. They have the best burgers I ever tasted and I visit them every time I visit Vegas. They are far less expensive than the over-rated Fatburger but many,many times better. Also , you may not believe this but although Circus Circus is hardly one of the best hotels in Vegas, they have the absolute best steakhouse. The steakhouse in Circus Circus has been voted the best many times and when you eat there you will see why. They have the best atmosphere, the best service, and the best food. Many steakhouses are a la carte meaning you have to purchase your entree, salad, potato, and vegetable separately, but here you get all that, including bread, with the purchase of your steak. I can't begin to describe how delicious every morsel of food was, but if you love steak try the Steakhouse at Circus Circus. Also if you are a fan of magic you would do well to check out the Steve Wyrick show at Planet Hollywood. I've seen Lance Burton four times and I've loved it each time. Lance has an endearing, engaging, fun personality and fast paced show perfectly suited to his classic magic and illusions. I've also seen David Copperfield, and for all his amazing tricks, I found his show slow, dull, and his personality felt as if he was phoning it in. Steve Wyrick is a mixture of the two. He combined Lance's personality with David Copperfield's amazing illusions. Steve's tricks, though, I felt were better than both of them. His theater is so intimate that every seat was a good seat and even though his show was hardly filled to capacity, he acted as if he were playing to a full house. Simply put, he was amazing. Check him out. I hope you enjoyed my review, I tried to be as thorough as possible, but as with any review just use it as a guideline but you can never really know until you experience it yourself. Enjoy!

Nov 29 2008 	New York New York city that never sleeps!	My boyfriend and I decided to get away for a Thanksgiving holiday. We both really enjoyed our 3 night stay here. Do not miss the Times Square Bar with the dueling pianos...I've been to places like this before (Pat O'briens) and they don't hold a candle to the excitement here. True professionals! I would definitely stay here again!

Nov 28 2008 	Good service room middle of the road	Stayed 10/23 and 10/24. Park Avenue RoomService was good, from valet staff to front desk staff to others we encountered.Likes- The room was clean- iPod dock clock radio- Comfortable bedLiked less:- Room was not near the elevator, as with most of these large resorts. However, because of the design of the hotel I felt like I kept walking around corners until eventually I found my room. Nov 28 2008 	I've Stayed Here Many Times But This Most Recent Visit Is Probably My Last	I have stayed at New York New York many times in the past few years, and I've always enjoyed it. My last stay before this most recent one was a year ago, and things have definitely changed there at the hotel. I was there from November 23rd to the 25th, 2008. I was very disappointed to discover that they are in the midst of redecorating and retheming their casino. Gone are the many artificial trees that made it seem like one was in Central Park. They even ripped out the stream and its bridge, and now it's all been covered with flooring and carpet! Instead of the many graceful trees, they have added these garish, modernisitic sculptures over the gaming tables and throughout the casino. They have strips of lights on top that change colors. They look very tacky and non-descript, and they are ugly. I talked to one of the game operators, and he said that they are trying to go for a more modern, sleek, hi-tech look in their casino. They are also building a circular bar in the center of the casino that will feature many, many flat screens TV and blaring rock music to add to that sleek, hip, modern feel. This bar will be called "Rok Vegas." The previous bar that was there was, I believe, called "The Big Apple." The rooms are still decorated the same. Mine was in good condition. I was on the 30th and had a great view of the Strip (which I requested when I made the online reservation a month ago). I always enjoy eating at the restaurant there called "Nine Fine Irishmen". The food has always been delicious. The prices are a bit on the high side, but it's worth it. When I ate there a couple days ago, they had live entertainment downstairs playing Irish-type music with singing. It was fun! There is NO buffet at New York New York, so I recommend going to the Planet Hollywood Hotel's buffet which is called "The Spice Market Buffet". For $30 for dinner, you get food from around the world! They have a Mexican, Italian, Mid-Eastern, Chinese, Japanese, American, and dessert section. The food is incredible! Very high-end and very delicious.I am really disappointed that New York New York's casino is in the process of being totally re-designed and rethemed to look "modern". I thought the Central Park theming was really unique and made it one-of-a-kind. Now it looks very ugly and plain. It lost all of its charm, in my opinion. I don't think I will be staying there again due to the drastic theme change in the casino.Also, I got charged twice for in-room Internet access. I caught that billing error upon checkout. They fixed it immediately.Still a fun place to stay (ride the roller-coaster!), but the casino is undergoing major changes that I think really detract from the overall experience. Like I said, I will probably begin staying elsewhere when I visit Las Vegas.

Nov 27 2008	I HOPE TO SEE EVERYTHING NEX TIME	We couldn't pick a better place to stay in Vegas; there is so much to see and enjoy at New York New York...from our window we watched the sunrise above the montains just before crashing after partying all night. I am sure every room has a great view. The Zumanity Show was awesome too!! The only little thing I have to share that perhaps it's not so good, is the fact that the only restricted floor is the 36th. floor; all other floors can be accessed by anyone and being Vegas, that was a surprise to me. I am sure they have great security but, in the mean time, who knows what could happen to any drunk person trying to make it to the hotel room...may be I'm not so used to be away from L.A. huh?Anyways, it is a great place and I look forward to staying there the next time I visit Vegas....

Nov 26 2008	Good Hotel in a Good Location	Very nice hotel. We were part of a group celebrating a 40th birthday party and 10 couples attended and stayed at this hotel. Overall the hotel was clean, no need to nit pick as you dont spend much time in the room anyways. The staff was friendly, not out-going, but friendly and the options for dining and entertainment were fulfilling. Both offer different levels of entertainment, while O'Sheas is more of a bar / casino and Carnvial Court is an outdoor area with shops / bar / stage / bands etc.In closing, New York - New York is nice, not elaborate(Venitian), but adequate for a fun stay in Las Vegas and I would definitely stay here again.

Nov 23 2008 	Always something going on	Stayed for two nights 11/20-11/21 and had a great time....my wife and I play alot so we built up a lot of table comps quickly...make sure you use them before you leave....they expire when you leave. Nov 20 2008 	Great Value for the money	NYNY is a very good value for your money, to sum it up. Nov 17 2008 	some frustrations	My husband and I spent four nights at the New York New York to celebrate our 20th anniversary, and in all honesty we would probably not return. Six weeks prior to our visit I had phoned and requested a king bed in a room that was not a long walk from the elevator. I explained that this was due to health reasons which sometimes make it difficult for me to walk long distances. We checked in at about 10pm, and finally got to our room at about 10:30. We could not have been further away! I phoned immediately and was told that was all they had but that they would move us in the morning. Upon receiving our new room, we noticed it was the exact same suite number, just ten floors higher! Again, I explained. This was the third time now. Their solution? I could take the elevator at the far end of the casino, then I wouldn't have such a far walk to my room. Hmmm. That makes sense.(!?)Other than the room issue, the restaurants were good. The room was ok. The lighting in the bathroom is pathetic. The casino was fairly quiet, which was fine for us. In hindsight, I would have prefered to be further down the strip and more central. We took cabs everywhere (because of the walking issue) and were impressed with the gentlemen working the cab desk outside...lots of good tips and suggestions. One last annoyance was the time share people working in the hotel. Steer clear!

Nov 17 2008 	Some good points some bad points	We stayed at the NY NY as part of our honeymoon in late October 2008. When we checked out we explicitly told the front desk person that we were checking out but going back to our room to get our bags. When we went back upstairs our keycard wouldnt work and we were told that we would have to call security.
